_exec_summary.SummaryText:
CHS Inc.



Risk Management Program Executive Summary





CHS is dedicated to preventing accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  The company stores and distributes anhydrous ammonia in pressure vessels. 



CHS believes that the health, safety, and preservation of our environment are critical components of effective management and business success.  As a company, we are committed to:



?Providing a secure and health conscious work environment for employees and visitors

?Conducting our business with always having value for the communities in which we operate and in the spirit of a good neighbor

?Meeting or exceeding the requirements of the environmental, health, & safety laws and regulations

?Training employees on the environmental, health & safety requirements of their jobs

?Working with government and other stakeholders to identify and solve problems



Anhydrous ammonia is stored in pressure vessels on properties.  It is transferred into the vessel from either semi-transports or rail cars and then placed into application equipment or nurse tanks.  The application equipment and/or nurse tanks are then transported to the farmer's field where the anhydrous ammonia is injected into the soil.



Anhydrous Ammonia (NH3) is stored in two 11,000-gallon water capacity cylinders that provide product for the conversion process that generates Ammonium Hydroxide (also referred to as aqua ammonia). Aqua manufacture is accomplished by dissolving anhydrous ammonia in water in an apparatus referred to as "the convertor". The convertor is a mixing chamber where Nh3 is introduced to water to create the ammonium hydroxide and then pumped through a cooling unit where the solution is cooled back down to ambient temperatures. A secondary cooling tower is in line for additional cooling of the aqua ammonia as it is piped into storage tanks.



An anhydrous ammonia storage tank is equipped with safety relief valves that are designed to release pressure in the event the tank become

s over pressurized.  The tanks are also equipped with excessive flow valves that are designed to shut down the flow of ammonia if a sudden release should happen.



In the event of a release from a storage facility that could impact the community, we advise those in the affected area to shelter in place until the plume dissipates.  Shelter in place involves everyone in the affected area seeking shelter indoors, shutting the windows and turning off the air conditioning and other ventilation systems.



CHS operates over 130 storage sites across the country.  In the past five years we have had very few releases from fixed storage facilities.  Vandalism and theft from nurse tanks has accounted for the some of our releases.



Our employees are trained in the characteristics and proper handling procedures for anhydrous ammonia.  They are equipped with the proper personal protective equipment for routine handling of the product.  The training also covers the basics in responding to emergencies involving ammonia releases and is available to assist the community first responders with technical information and advice.



CHS provide training, training material and emergency response information to each fire department with jurisdiction over our locations. We also meet with concerned citizens and other interested parties about our risk management program and anhydrous ammonia safety in general.



CHS continually updates the training provided to its employees.  Employees are trained in proper handling, facility inspections, ammonia characteristics; emergency procedures and must review the emergency response plan, emergency action plan, and site security plan annually.



CHS is proud of its past safety performance and is continuing to look for new ways to improve its anhydrous ammonia safety program.
